    Farmer agitation and issue of remunerative price

    Nagendra Chatterjee     10 minute read    Read in Hindi   HOME    July 03, 2021   

    About 90 percent farmers of the country have their holding size of less than one hectare. They do not produce so much, which can be sold in market for a profitable price. Hence, the demand of profitable price has no any sense for them. This is the reason that small and marginal farmers are not adhering to farmer agitations. So, the farmer leaders should make the demand of remunerative prices in broader perspective.

    Translated from किसान आंदोलन और लाभकारी मूल्य का सवाल
    (Appeal to farmer leaders)

    In recent days the turbulences among farmers are on continuously rising. Apart from the farmers agitations, strikes, demonstrations scattered throughout the country, in 2018 – foot march of dissatisfied farmers flooded from Nasik to Mumbai. In Delhi also, many thousands of farmers gathered on demonstration. Before the blaze of these disturbances were extinguished, the introduction of three new farm laws refuelled the fire and in no time several thousand farmers sat on the borders of Delhi in January 2020. Instead of the fact that these farmers are treated as foreign intruder, their strike is still going on.

    भारतीय किसान विद्रोह और ग्वाटेमाला की भूख

    दिल्ली के सिंघू बॉर्डर पर किसान केवल इसलिए नहीं आंदोलनरत हैं कि उनकी अस्मिता ख़तरे में है। अस्मिता तो ख़तरे में है ही। बल्कि वे इसलिए भी लड़ रहे हैं ताकि इस ...

    Mainly the farmers of Punjab, Haryana and Western Uttar Pradesh are participating in this current agitation. Far away from their own villages and houses, for more than seven months the farmers are on the strike at dozens of locations at Delhi borders like - Tikri, Sindhu, Gazipur etc under the banner of ‘Kisan Sanyukt Morcha’ (Farmers Joint Front) with the vow of returning home only after withdrawal of the farm laws. During this period, for many reasons above 300 farmers lost their lives. (As per published information, between 20 November, 2020 and 20 February, 2021 some 248 farmers got martyred.) The government has stopped talking after few initial rounds and on other end even with frequent sacrifices of their lives the farmers are adamant with the vow on their demand.

    The leaders of joint front of farmers (Sanyukt Kisan Morcha) have tried to spread their agitation throughout the nation. They succeeded to the extent that there had been greater inquests (jury, known as - Mahapanchayat) convened at many locations and throughout the country there had been some sparce strikes and demonstrations. But in other locations, it is not as vast as it is in Punjab, Haryana. The farmers from other parts of country though have sympathy with these farmers performing strikes at Sindhu, Tikri, Gazipur borders, with the question of ‘life and death’ but, they don’t have the same anger and neither any active participation in the agitation. It needs to find out the reasons and correct the weaknesses.

    Revolt of Indian Farmers and Hunger of Guatemala

    The reasons lie in the demands of the farmer movement. The present farmers movement, which arose after new farm laws have three main demands – first, all three farm acts withdrawal without any condition; second, guarantee of minimum support price and third, reduction in electricity tariff.

    The first demand came after the incept of new farm law and it energised the present movement. If the laws are implemented then, in few days all the arable land will be under the possession of corporates, either on lease or on contract and the owner of land would become stranger for his own land, even on the paper it may be his own land without real control, as it is happening in those countries where contract farming exists. In practice the real owner of land losing the freedom either will have to work on own piece of land as labourer for wage or will get displaced and look for other means for survival. The farmers with small piece of arable land make the majority, who for survival of their family grew grains in own land, now would not be able to feed their family from the received rental amount. These small farmers produce grains for family consumption and earn a little cash by selling lemon, chilli, cauliflower etc in village market (‘Haat’) and by rearing cow or goat. With the corporate farming all possibilities of living with freedom will get wiped. The capitalists will never consider the food problem of the country, rather they will consider their commercial interests in growing crops. It will not only result in reduction in availability of food grains but also varieties in food grains will get reduced. The free hands granted for private storage of grains will generate artificial shortage and the tormenting people from hunger will have to avail the stored grains on very high price. There is tremendous rise in hunger, malnutrition and unemployment in those countries where such laws are enforced. The Oxfam report on Guatemala is an example. The farmers are opposing the new farm act with the fear of the possibility of such terrifying situation.

    Second main demand is ‘Minimum Support Price’. The demand for profitable price is old demand. Following the recommendation of Swaminathan commission, the central government every year evaluates the cost on selected crops to decide minimum support price to fix it to one and half times the cost, now the government claims that the minimum support price is two times rather than one and half times. With repeated assurance of government that the minimum support price regime might not be withdrawn, farmers believe that on paper there would be no withdrawal but the provisions in the new farm laws practically limits or inactivates the government procurement and farmers would be helpless in selling their crops to traders on throw away prices.

    Till now government declares minimum support price on 23 crops. The states where the ‘Mandis’ (markets or say corn exchange) are functioning the farmers are selling their crops on government declared price and if not getting much enough still getting above the cost. The farmers of Punjab, Haryana etc are in this category of beneficiary. According to report published in August 2018, “NABARD - All India Rural Financial Inclusion Survey 2016-17”, it quotes – the average monthly income of farmers in Punjab as Rs. 23,133 and in Haryana it is Rs. 18,496. It has resulted from the minimum support price regime. But this is not same for entire nation.

    The minimum support price is fixed by centre but, determining the system of procurement is responsibility of states. Hence, there is difference in procurement system among states. For example, Bihar has dissolved the agriculture markets and procured through PACS (Primary Agricultural Credit Society). A certain target for grain procurement quantity is given to PACS, it can not procure above the target even if there is much more production in the area. Taking advantage of the limit for the procurement quantity and delay in payments the middlemen become active and purchase the produce far below the fixed price and with their personal nexus sell it in same PACS, earning huge profit. In other states, the helplessness in selling their grains at lower price, the farmers hardly meet the cost of production, the profitable price is a distant thing for them. The same report of NABARD reveals that average monthly income of farmers in Madhya Pradesh is Rs. 7,175, in Uttar Pradesh it is Rs. 6,668, in West Bengal it is Rs. 7,756 and likewise in other states. The procurement system in other states has its role in low incomes of farmers in other states compared to that in Panjab and Haryana.

    शिक्षा नीति 2020 और सामाजिक विभेद

    नीति राजसत्ता की वह परिकल्पना होती है, जो यह दिखाती है कि व्यवस्था को किन रास्तों से होकर कहाँ तक ले जाना है। इसकी भूमिका दिशा-निर्देशक की होती है। राज्य नीत...

    This is the reason that unlike the farmers of Punjab and Haryana, who become restless expecting the danger in termination of remunerative price or minimum support price, the farmers from other corners of country are not showing any such sentiment as they are deprived of price benefits. Therefore, the passion and belligerence with which the farmers of said states are agitating, instead of sympathy, this belligerence, do or die feeling is not seen in the farmers from other parts of country, as they don’t find their interest in it. Ironically, they find it advantageous in getting free from the loss ridden farming or rent out their land. The reason of the farmers agitation not becoming widespread should be looked into the interrelation of the procurement policy.

    Even if the profitable price is ensured for all the farmers, then also there are more issues on its present system. Whom does the profitable price or minimum support price concern? For the present system it is for those farmers who grow over and above their family consumption, which needs to be sold. Those who grow more will take benefit of earning more. Growing more crop depends on large size of arable land. it means that the constituent element of this system is in favour of the countable capitalist farmers. But, the picture of this country is different, the majority of farmers are not in this category. According to agricultural census 2015-16 there are 89 percent farmers having holding size less than one hectare of arable land and among them 35 percent have holding size of 0.4 hectare. A family in India means 4.5 persons. It means there are 90 percent farmers growing as much food as it barely meets the requirement of their families. They don’t have any opportunity to sell their crops for remunerative price and there is no any benefit on growing for own needs. Hence, those from the majority of farmers, this agitation gives impression that it is not for them, as they don’t see any benefit for them in the profitable price and they are indifferent about it.

    There are also dangers of profitable price. There are only 23 farm products for which the government fixes the minimum support price. All products are also not procured by government. This is only a formality. It is natural that the crop expected to get better price would be grown more. For this interrelation of profit and production the farmers of Punjab and some other states have grown so much of wheat that India became second producer of wheat in the world after China and in absence of proper storage almost 20,000,000 tons of wheat gets rotten every year. The coarse crops like KODO, SAMA, MANDUA have no any fixation of profitable price, these are vanishing gradually. In this way the profitable pricing system is harming the food variation that is essential for healthy living.

    Then what to do? The best can be that not only selected 23 crops but, all products from farms and related to farmers, should be purchased by government on profitable price and make these available for consumption at bearable prices. Of course, the farmers with large holdings will take the advantage, they will have very good profit also, the farmers with small holdings who only grow for their requirements will also become beneficiary on their produced crops and other farm related products. Then they will feel their association with the demand of profitable price and would stand in its support. With this policy, not only the small farmers will become beneficiary, also the variety of crops will be preserved and there will be less friction in society and healthy society will emerge. At present, the welfare-oriented path of capitalist democracy can not have any better option than this.

    What will the government do of total procurement of farm products and how will she compensate the loss from the subsidy? This question needs to be responded. First thing to keep in mind is that still the government is providing food grains on concessional rates. Hence, there is nothing to plan for any new device. India grows more than enough grains far above the food supply, it is said that India alone can feed entire world for six months. To compensate the loss in providing food grains to own citizens at subsidy, she would have enough surplus that could be sold to manufacturers for making industrially processed agricultural products and in foreign at higher prices above the cost. In this way there will be benefit to small farmers along with the big farmers and the government also, even if the government to be considered as commercial entity and not the welfare organisation still there will be no loss.

    Hence, the agenda of farmers agitation should not only be the remunerative price, but it should be procurement of all farm products by government at remunerative price. It will serve the interest of all farmers and they will actively support the agitation. The government, prudent government should not have any hesitation in accepting it.
